[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/community-india?msg=oWnG2Ai5NBiXivLTa) @codeUncode Peer gossiping initially with the peers mentioned in the core peers section in the compose file and then discovering others as well. Hi @VipinB, sincere apologies. We missed scheduling this today's meeting well in advance. I just spoke to Kamlesh, and we are good to schedule next meeting either on Thursday (regular India chapter meeting day) or next Monday, which is 15th.
Please suggest a day and time, so that we can circulate the agenda...

Next Monday the 15th would be the best for me as I will be at the zkproof standards meeting in San Francisco this week. I want to do a brief presentation on the Identity Working Group (maybe 10 minutes) and its activities. The next meeting of ID WG will be on 17th April.

Hello guys, as we made the second call of the ID WG at 00:00 UTC for the benefit of APAC members, we will now move it to 01:00 UTC  (as it will be convenient for everyone, including those in IST). We have two times suitable for India; 4 pm UTC and 01:00 UTC. We have participation from Japan and Australia in the second call. Please let us know what else the Indian community would like to discuss and contribute in Identity Working Group. What would be fantastic would be any work that you could share on Identity in India, especially the consent layer in the India Stack and how this can be integrated into Blockkchain/DLTs based in Hyperledger. This will have a direct influence on the solutions that we develop in Hyperledger DLT for Identity and Access Management. Any open documentation or data or code on these regulations also could help.  Hope to make a short pitch on this on our next community call(hopefully on the 15th). Thanks
The ID WG calls are every two weeks on Wednesdays/Thursdays there are two calls with almost the same agenda on the same day (for myself in EDT-US East Coast).

Having a community of HL certified members available to guide exam takers will help. Suggestions are to set up a RocketChat channel focused on certification, have dedicated meetups & form study groups. Perhaps arrange for training if required.

# Copyright IBM Corp. All Rights Reserved.
#
# SPDX-License-Identifier: Apache-2.0
#

# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
# "OrdererOrgs" - Definition of organizations managing orderer nodes
# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
OrdererOrgs:
  # ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
  # Orderer
  # ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
  - Name: Orderer
    Domain: example.com
    # ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
    # "Specs" - See PeerOrgs below for complete description
    # ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
    Specs:
      - Hostname: orderer
      - Hostname: orderer2
      - Hostname: orderer3
      - Hostname: orderer4
      - Hostname: orderer5

# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
# "PeerOrgs" - Definition of organizations managing peer nodes
# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
PeerOrgs:
  # ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
  # Org1
  # ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
  - Name: Org1
    Domain: org1.example.com
    EnableNodeOUs: true
    # ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
    # "Specs"
    # ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
    # Uncomment this section to enable the explicit definition of hosts in your
    # configuration.  Most users will want to use Template, below
    #
    # Specs is an array of Spec entries.  Each Spec entry consists of two fields:
    #   - Hostname:   (Required) The desired hostname, sans the domain.
    #   - CommonName: (Optional) Specifies the template or explicit override for
    #                 the CN.  By default, this is the template:
    #
    #                              "{{.Hostname}}.{{.Domain}}"
    #
    #                 which obtains its values from the Spec.Hostname and
    #                 Org.Domain, respectively.
    # ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
    # Specs:
    #   - Hostname: foo # implicitly "foo.org1.example.com"
    #     CommonName: foo27.org5.example.com # overrides Hostname-based FQDN set above
    #   - Hostname: bar
    #   - Hostname: baz
    # ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
    # "Template"
    # ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
    # Allows for the definition of 1 or more hosts that are created sequentially
    # from a template. By default, this looks like "peer%d" from 0 to Count-1.
    # You may override the number of nodes (Count), the starting index (Start)
    # or the template used to construct the name (Hostname).
    #
    # Note: Template and Specs are not mutually exclusive.  You may define both
    # sections and the aggregate nodes will be created for you.  Take care with
    # name collisions
    # ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
    Template:
      Count: 2
      # Start: 5
      # Hostname: {{.Prefix}}{{.Index}} # default
    # ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
    # "Users"
    # ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
    # Count: The number of user accounts _in addition_ to Admin
    # ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
    Users:
      Count: 1
  # ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
  # Org2: See "Org1" for full specification
  # ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
  - Name: Org2
    Domain: org2.example.com
    EnableNodeOUs: true
    Template:
      Count: 2
    Users:
      Count: 1

There are 2 parts to this.
(1) Asking for BFT behavior in HLF which is not yet implemented / available.
(2) Storing the keys at the client, I guess you're talking about Fabric client here. Could you explain your current architecture? Are you building a server which has wallet stored and then a client that talks via the server?

One approach would be for you to store list of trusted certs in a world state. Install a administrator chaincode and let it verify end user's cert. All the client transactions are to be signed by an entity that is rooted to the certificate that your chaincode trusts. Hope this was helpful.

Looking at the logs, the first screenshot seems to be normal, I don't see any issues there. It is just adding new batches to the block that is being created.
Since you're saying it is a production network, I believe you have tuned your network to maximum transactions in a block.

Second screenshot says that you have a static peering network. You will have to give out more information. This gossip layer exception does not necessarily end up in bad behavior. Until the networking layer is moved to rust, you will see these dumps. These are not well handled.
Can you share more information: what are you experiencing, what makes you think there is a problem etc?
@ksanjayk did you update your local terminal and set the required variables?
As per the document the script file is supposed to initialize your dev environment `source magnetocorp.sh`
If this is not happening, please raise a ticket to the Fabric team. Give me more logs, I can help to debug it further.

@arsulegai 
This is the scenario. Client is firing a transaction which is invalid as per our transaction processor validations that we have put. But as opposed to the expected behaviour of replying with INVALID status, blockchain seems to add it to candidate block queue and instead sends back UNKNOWN status which implies to clients that something is wrong with the blockchain. We are confused whe n all the nodes' transaction processor is logging it as an invalid transaction, why is blockchain not as a whole rejecting the block as invalid and instead keeping it as candidate block

Batch and block are different things. Transaction execution happens only at the time of block creation. When you say blockchain, I assume it to be the validator node. Validator waits for the transaction result and then adds to the candidate block. If the TP is written to send invalid transaction, it won't be added to the block. Candidate block is a term that is used to represent block under construction.
Transaction Processor is throwing exception saying it's an invalid block. But still the batch is added as candidate block. I wonder what could be the possible issue.
Transaction Processor is throwing exception saying it's an invalid transaction payload. But still the batch is added as candidate block. I wonder what could be the possible issue.
Is it the only pending transaction that node has?
There is a known issue around that

Yes. Let me give a brief of the scenario

I submit a faulty transaction: Transaction error throws error, but still validator keeps it and I see log CandidateBlock: add_batch
Now if we keep submitting faulty transactions, the above scenario keeps happening. 
Submission of a correct transaction results in a block getting comitted.

When you submit the good transaction, block gets created. This does not include invalid transaction in it. It removes the invalid transaction from the pending batches (that is how transactions are sent to the validator) pool.

The known issue around invalid transaction is -- validator should ignore if a transaction is invalid, but it won't if it's the only transaction in the validator. This was unintentional in the code. Also, there is a pending PR on that and is not merged from a long time.
Sawtooth 2.0 release wouldn't have this issue because it will follow different design around this part of the code.
Hope this clarifies all your questions

It is not released yet. Please join the community meeting today, there will be updates. Find the meeting information in #sawtooth-core-dev

What's the better way to have a health check on sawtooth nodes ? To address the issue of stuck validator nodes which gets fixed on node restart, we are thinking of having kubernetes readiness probe in place which would perform health check on sawtooth validator pod. But I am unable to find any relevant documentation on it. My basic approach that I thought on the top of my head was to execute `sawtooth batch status --url http://rest-api:8008 $(sawtooth batch list --url http://rest-api:8008 | awk 'FNR == 2 { print $1 }') | awk 'FNR == 3 {print}'` and check the commit status but it turned out sawtooth batch status only returns commited batches.

It depends on how you define the health, if the health check is whether service is up or not then it is easier. If you're defining health check as whether block is being produced or not, it is user triggered random event. Alerting based on logs is the best way.

For us ( basically what clients expect) blocks are being committed is the metric to judge if things are good. Do you have reference to any procedure to accomplish this. We are a bit reluctant to submitting batch every time liveness probe runs as that would result in a tremendous amount of chain size.

Attach an event listener to know if a transaction has been successfully put into the block. If you don't see the event in sometime, let's say 10min, then query for the status, if it's unknown then send it again.

Hello everyone.   Great to be in here, I wanted to update the community on our updated capabilities with XBOM on Hyperledger Fabric we presented in late 2020.  

We presented to Hyperledger NYC and Denver Meetups. Please watch the recording of the premier of ClassFungibleAsset and subclass ClassSmartAsset for enablement of Fungible and Non-Fungible Assets in our GlobalOS, XBOM a First Class Object mode on Hyperledger.

This is a command line demo which clearly shows how blockchain advances without any smart contracts using DataGrid Token ($DGT) and wrapped ETH ($WETH) as examples.

Again, everything works as advertised, this release is for our XBOM dev environment and enterprise TestNet for PoC. The use cases for enterprise, the assets would be pharmaceuticals, spark pugs, bolts, coal, etc in a supply chain.

Pay Attention to the enablement of a Globally UniqueID for every account and every object.
